stories.text:
Hi all , I m a developer but a bad forex trader, I built Forex Neuron,it s a free forex signals provider backed by A.I for short-term trading.

This app monitors pairs rates in real-times, when the algorithm spots a signal a notification is broadcasted on Telegram, Twitter, facebook and Discord, signals are executed in real time and if it reaches the profit or loss price it will also send a notification.

the web app is free, no account required “ I m not interested in your data, I have a life and I respect yours “, to get real-time notification on signals you have just to follow the Twitter, Facebook, Discord, but I recommend Telegram it's the best and the fast way to get notifications.

Signals are not 100% accurate, spotting the right pattern in a noisy data is very hard especially for short terms, but I'm working on it mostly every day to improve the algorithm, it's the main reason why it's free and friendly advice never buy a forex signal service it's usually a scam , if someone can predict forex with 100% accuracy he will not need to sell his signals.

I have worked on this project since 2016, I have created many versions, some better than others and this is the last version.I'm trying to keep this web app trustable as much as possible, no data manipulation, no loss hiding and everything is executed in real time.

I plan to add many other features to this web app; a social network for traders, EA for Metatrader, prediction for crypto …etc depending on my free time :)

Your feedback will be appreciated so please feel free to comment and ask your questions , thank you all for your time .
stories.title: Show HN: Free forex signals provider backed by A.I
Twitter Grapples with an Elon Musk Problem
Ask HN: How important is ontology engineering today?

stories.text:
I grew up a millennial tech geek, spending my days lurking on Tom's Hardware, playing and modding video games, tinkering with code and watching Star Trek. Wherever I looked at the world's problems, more technology seemed to be the answer.

Nowadays I'm a software dev and tech entrepreneur. At best, technology bores me. At worst, it terrifies me. Today's startups are solving the most boring problems imaginable. Gadgets are a snoozfest. Programming languages and frameworks seem to be running in circles.

We seem to be experiencing diminishing returns on tech for the past few years. More tech is no longer necessarily better. Is this just a phase before the next big industrial revolution?

When did this start, and when is the drought going to be over?
stories.title: Ask HN: When Did Tech Stop Being Cool?
What Is a Monoid in Haskell?
